And finally, from Pablo Neruda’s Ode to Salt

Dust of the sea, in you
the tongue receives a kiss
from ocean night:
taste imparts to every seasoned
dish your ocean essence

This 20 yr old article led me to better salt, and I imported the Portuguese flor de sal for almost as long

As global shipping begins to return to something close to pre pandemic normalcy, I hope we can bring it back

Like it or not, Cargill and it’s ilk aren’t going away, and they’ll keep selling cheap food produced by some kind of exploitation

But we can choose where we spend our money

Adjusting to a different salt is a real issue

We worked with our Norwegian sea salt producer to make a kosher-style sea salt with the same density as DC

It’s not cheap, but the price reflects its true cost

I can afford alternatives to DC, and if you do they’re not that hard to find

Better grocery stores usually carry sea salt, and there’s always Amazon (I know, another exploitive biz, but this is the world we live in)

https://www.amazon.com/sea-salt/s?k=sea+salt

It’s true that DC is much less expensive, but that low price is only possible because someone else pays the true costs

The environmental advocacy group Mighty Earth named Cargill the worst company in the world.

Since I import sea salt, it’s fair to say I have an interest in promoting DC alternatives

So here’s another opinion, Alicia Kennedy on salt

If you don’t mind bumping the profits of an awful corporation, keep buying it

But here are some reasons why you shouldn’t

The TLDR answer is that Cargill decided to make more money:

“...Cargill aims to increase the annual revenue from Diamond Crystal from $3 million to $50 million”
